BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The avalanches can in isolated cases reach large size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The northwesterly wind has transported the new snow significantly. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong northwesterly wind, wind slabs formed in the last two days. The mostly small wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The danger of slab avalanches in particular above approximately 2500 m is within the upper range of danger level 2 (moderate). Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
Backcountry touring and snowshoe hiking call for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The northwesterly wind has transported the new snow significantly. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low altitude only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The clearly visible wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind has transported some snow. As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2000 m. Above the tree line the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
Fresh wind slabs are in many cases extensive and to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant. They are to be avoided as far as possible.
Several mostly small natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of the moderate to strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 10 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2000 m. Thus far the wind has been strong to storm force in some localities over a wide area. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2000 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind the prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The clearly visible wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind has transported the loosely bonded old snow. As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep slopes above approximately 2300 m.
At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the wind slabs are larger.
Fresh wind slabs are easy for the trained eye to recognise but to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
Several mostly small natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of the moderate to strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 5 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2000 m. Today the wind was moderate to strong over a wide area.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind the prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Especially on wind-loaded slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some places wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
In some localities light snowfall. In all regions warming.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m.
At high altitude the wind slabs are larger.
Fresh wind slabs are easy for the trained eye to recognise but to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
Isolated whumpfing sounds can indicate the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be prone to triggering in some places. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 1900 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted and weak. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution. On shady slopes a moderate danger of dry avalanches will persist.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can in some places be released by large loads and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for a certain restraint. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Wind slabs can be released, mostly by large loads and reach large size in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of northwesterly wind, brittle wind slabs formed. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and has a loosely bonded surface. This applies in particular in shady places that are protected from the wind. In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of last week are clearly recognisable. These represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The sometimes large wind slabs are clearly recognisable. They are to be avoided as far as possible in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised in all aspects in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 2300 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places. The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. They are unlikely to be released now.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The large surface-area wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering. Over a wide area 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. On Wednesday as a consequence of the strong southwesterly wind there will be an increase in the danger of dry avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise and prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released easily in some cases above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. In isolated cases avalanches are medium-sized. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places. These are mostly rather small but can in some cases be released easily.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular in the south 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. On Wednesday as a consequence of the strong southwesterly wind there will be an increase in the danger of dry avalanches. The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 10 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. On Wednesday as a consequence of the strong southwesterly wind there will be an increase in the danger of dry avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The older wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In particular on very steep slopes more mostly small avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The meteorological conditions facilitated a strengthening of the snowpack.
Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
In some localities light snowfall. In all regions warming.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. On Wednesday as a consequence of the strong southwesterly wind there will be only a slight increase in the danger of dry avalanches. The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be quite favourable.
Weakly bonded old snow above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are not ruled out.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1500 m hardly any snow is lying. Above approximately 1500 m a little snow is lying. The snowpack remains generally stable. Especially gullies and bowls are precarious. Here small wind slabs formed. These are shallow and can be released in isolated cases. These avalanche prone locations are rather rare.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Especially on wind-loaded slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall on Wednesday above approximately 1500 m. In the afternoon as a consequence of the new snow there will be an increase in the avalanche danger to level 2 (moderate).
